plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: An evergreen perennial known for its early winter to early spring blooming period, often flowering through late winter into March. Its white to pinkish flowers bring color to gardens before many other plants bloom.
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, the Christmas Rose is not a true rose but a member of the buttercup family (Ranunculaceae).

plants.name: Magnolia stellata
plants.description: A small deciduous tree that bursts into star-shaped white flowers in early spring, sometimes blooming as early as late February through March, often before the leaves emerge.
plants.location: Native to Japan, widely cultivated in temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Star Magnolia flowers are among the earliest magnolias to bloom and are prized for their showy, fragrant flowers that herald spring.

plants.name: Wattle (Acacia pycnantha)
plants.description: Australia’s national floral emblem, this shrub or small tree produces bright golden-yellow, fluffy spherical flowers that bloom in late winter to early spring.
plants.bloomingSeason: July to October (Southern Hemisphere late winter to spring, overlapping March in northern Australia)
plants.funFact: The Golden Wattle’s bright color inspired Australia’s national colors, green and gold.

plants.name: Crocus vernus
plants.description: A bulbous perennial flowering plant that produces vibrant cup-shaped flowers in shades of purple, white, and yellow. One of the earliest signifiers of spring in temperate gardens and meadows.
plants.location: Europe and parts of the Middle East, widely naturalized elsewhere
plants.funFact: Crocuses are known for their edible stigmas, which are harvested to create the spice saffron, though this is specific to Crocus sativus.
